(
5 specimens

of

by present designation, female: “Ega / S. America : Brazil / Sharp Coll. 1903 – 313 /

Type . D. S. Amazons / Lectotype

des. 2007 ” ( BMNH ).

, female: “ Type / Ega / S. America : Brazil / idem third label /

Sterculia amazonica Asiain, Márquez & Morrone
des. 2007 ” ( BMNH ).

of

Sterculia pauloensis
, Type D. S. / Holotype ” ( BMNH ).

of

Sterculia carinata Asiain, Márquez & Morrone
des. 2007 ” ( FMNH ).
Holotype
of

, female: “Notó, Parana / Brasilien /
Sterculia aureipennis Bernh.
Typus Staudinger / idem fourth label” ( FMNH ).

T. F. A. Camp., Cerro de la Neblina,
0° 49 ’N

66 °0’W

III. 1984
( FMNH , 1 ?).
Variation. Great variation in color and body length. Generally the smaller specimens have a rounded head, less convex dorsally, and shorter mandibles.

Nomenclatural notes. The revision of the holotype specimen of
P. pauloensis (
Sharp, 1876
)
, a previous synonym of
P. fulgens (
Fabricius, 1793
)
, allowed us to recognize that the names
P. amazonicus (
Sharp, 1876
)
,
P. carinatus (
Bernhauer, 1916
)
,
P. aureipennis (
Bernhauer, 1927
)
and P. v i o l a c e u s (
Olivier, 1795
) refer to a single Amazonian species, P. f u l g e n s , which was previously confused even with Mexican specimens that actually belong to
P. simplicicollis
. Even Sharp ( 1867 ) was not completely sure that
P. amazonicus
and
P. pauloensis
, which were described in the same paper, were in fact two different species.
